summary: This document is an email chain from August 13, 2019, between attorneys discussing the aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody. It includes a detailed preservation request from Epstein's family attorney for all evidence related to his detention and death, and communications with federal prosecutors regarding the ongoing investigation and indictment process.

persons.name: Martin Weinberg
persons.context: He is the primary author of the detailed preservation request for evidence related to Epstein's detention and death, sent on behalf of Epstein's family. He is coordinating with other attorneys and the government.

persons.name: Michael Miller
persons.context: He is a recipient of the emails, copied on the preservation request, and involved in scheduling calls regarding the US v. Epstein case.

persons.name: Reid Weingarten
persons.context: He is a recipient of the emails, copied on the preservation request and government updates regarding Epstein's death.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the criminal case (US v. Epstein) and the individual whose death in custody on August 10, 2019, is the central topic of the preservation request and investigation discussions.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as having personal counsel who should also receive the preservation request for evidence related to Jeffrey Epstein's death.

connections.description: Weinberg is acting as legal counsel for Epstein's family, sending a preservation request for evidence related to Epstein's detention and death.
They are coordinating on legal matters related to the US v. Epstein case, scheduling calls, and sharing information.
Both are attorneys copied on the same emails and legal communications regarding Epstein's case and death.
Both are attorneys receiving updates from the government and involved in the same legal discussions.
Mark Epstein is identified as Jeffrey Epstein's brother, whose personal counsel is to be sent the preservation request.

events.title: Epstein's imprisonment begins
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was taken into federal custody.

events.title: Reported attempted suicide in MCC
events.description: An occurrence investigated as an attempted suicide by Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

events.title: Night before Epstein's death
events.description: The evening leading up to Epstein's death, for which video and staff records are requested.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the MCC. The Attorney General and FBI initiated investigations into the death.

events.title: Attorney coordination and preservation request
events.description: Emails between attorneys scheduling a call and the formal submission of a detailed evidence preservation request to the government regarding Epstein's detention and death.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) on August 10, 2019.

Epstein's family attorney, Martin Weinberg, sent a comprehensive preservation request for all evidence related to Epstein's detention, treatment, and death, including video, staff logs, medical records, and any note found in his cell.
There was a prior incident on July 23, 2019, investigated as an attempted suicide by Epstein at the MCC.
The FBI and the Attorney General initiated investigations into Epstein's death immediately following the event.
The government's indictment against Epstein was still 'in progress' at the time of his death, as noted in the correspondence.
